description: A stunning mountain retreat known for its jagged peaks, the Benedictine monastery, and the Black Madonna. Great for spiritual visits and short hikes.
notes: Train departs from Plaça Espanya station.
Cable car offers scenic ascent — avoid if afraid of heights.
Arrive early to beat the crowds and fog.

description: An ancient Roman city by the sea featuring well-preserved ruins, sandy beaches, and a charming old town.
notes: Wear walking shoes — many cobblestone streets and elevation changes.
Museum pass grants access to multiple Roman sites.
Great for history lovers and photographers.

description: A medieval city with a beautifully preserved Jewish quarter, Game of Thrones filming locations, and ancient walls you can walk.
notes: Buy AVE tickets in advance to get a good price.
Popular day trip — can get crowded midday.
Combine with Figueres for Dali Museum if staying overnight.

description: A postcard-perfect Costa Brava town with a medieval walled fortress on the beach, crystal-clear waters, and a relaxed vibe.
highlights: Tossa de Mar Castle and walls
notes: Go early in summer — beach gets packed.
Great combination of beach and history.
Good spot for lunch and souvenir shopping.

description: Two charming, neighboring Costa Brava villages known for their whitewashed houses, crystal-clear coves, and relaxing seaside atmosphere. Connected by the scenic Camí de Ronda coastal trail, they offer a perfect blend of beach, nature, and Catalan charm.
distanceFromBarcelona: 2.25 hours by bus (with transfer) or 2 hours by car
highlights: Camí de Ronda trail between Calella and Llafranc
Platja de Llafranc and its quiet bay
notes: Requires a transfer in Palafrugell if coming by bus.
Quiet, upscale, and less touristy than other Costa Brava towns.
Ideal for couples, photographers, and relaxed travelers.
Great area to stay overnight if you want peace and views.
